awd_titl_txt: Populating a Radiocarbon Database of North America, Phase III
awd_abstract_narration:
Radiocarbon dating provides archaeologists with dates on organic materials (especially charcoal from hearths) that are less than 45,000 years old.  It is the primary method that North American archaeologists use, and millions of dollars in federal and other funding has been spent in obtaining thousands of such dates from archaeological sites. Researchers around the world now use the changing abundance of radiocarbon dates over time as a way to reconstruct population over time, and thus to provide an important piece of human history: where and when did populations rise and decline?  How fast? How does population change relate to environmental change, technological innovation, population density, subsistence, warfare, and emigration, social and political organization?  This project has already compiled dates from the 11 western U.S. states (~42,000) and 12 Plains/Central states (~14,000); it will now move on to compile dates from the remaining eastern third of the US.  It is not only the dates themselves that are compiled, but also associated contextual information that researchers need to "clean" the database to create a sample useful for their specific research questions. The data will become publicly and freely available through the Canadian Archaeological Radiocarbon Database, a large and growing international radiocarbon database. It will provide researchers with a useful tool to investigate research questions in several disciplines including archaeology, paleontology, and genetics, and help move North American archaeology toward its next frontier, "Big Data," since archaeology's strength is its ability to test hypotheses against patterns in data across vast reaches of space and time.

This project focuses on the question of prehistoric rates of population growth and decline. It has already discovered that the long-term rates of growth of agricultural populations are the same as earlier hunting and gathering populations, and implies that rapid population growth is only a feature of modern human life, a product of nineteenth century technological advances in food production, trade, and medical knowledge. The project has also detected a pre-AD 1500 decline in Native American populations, the cause of which is under investigation and, combined with international data, remarkable synchronicity in global population trends of the past 10,000 years. To achieve its goal the project is also investigating the "best practices" of statistical analysis of large samples of radiocarbon dates. Rises and declines in the number of dates per unit time is assumed to track similar rises and declines in human population. There is reason to be cautious as several variables could modify this relationship, for example, research bias, the systematic loss of dates over time due to preservation, and the effects of the standard procedure used to convert radiocarbon ages in familiar calendar dates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
North American archaeologists date sites primarily using radiocarbon dates. This technique dates anything organic (though some materials, such as charcoal, are better than others) as long as those items are < 50,000 years old.  Large numbers of radiocarbon dates can be used to track changes in the size of past human populations, using the simple assumption that more dates = more people and fewer dates = fewer people. However, inference is not simple for several reasons, e.g., radiocarbon dates are statistical approximations, with a known level of error for each date (i.e., a mean and standard deviation); dates must be ?calibrated? to account for changes in the amount of carbon-14 in the atmosphere over time; samples of dates may reflect the foci of archaeological research; and organic material decays over time, so declining numbers of dates with age may reflect population AND organic decay. Nonetheless, tracking human populations matters because change in the size of a human population is important to understanding why human histories took the particular paths that they did. While house counts, settlement size, or ceramic sherd density can be used in some regions radiocarbon dates is the only data source that can be used across all parts of the US, and, in fact, the world. 

Radiocarbon dates are difficult to analyze statistically, and the field is working out the ?best practices? for these data. To do so, though, it needs the data. Therefore, our project?s simple goal was to compile the radiocarbon dates for the lower 48 states (Canadian colleagues have worked on both Canada and Alaska). The data are curated in, and available to vetted researchers by the Canadian Archaeological Radiocarbon Database (CARD), which is housed at the University of British Columbia, and which had already been collecting radiocarbon dates from the US. We saw no need to reinvent the wheel, and instead of creating a competing database, we collaborated with our Canadian colleagues. Note that CARD contains a public side that requires no vetting.

We compiled dates from smaller databases, journals, books, dissertations, and ?grey literature? (limited distribution reports largely produced through archaeology done for compliance with federal legislation) published since 1950, the year that radiocarbon dating was invented. We sought to record a variety of pieces of information for each date, including the lab number, the material dated (charcoal, bone, plant material, textile, etc.), the specific taxa (e.g., bison bone, pine charcoal), the location (to county only to protect sites from looting), the measured and conventional age, the radiocarbon method (there are two major ones, conventional and AMS, or ?accelerator? dating), the site name and Smithsonian number, and information on the date?s context (e.g., associated with a grave, from a structural beam, hearth).

We wrote hundreds of emails to investigators to correct errors or discrepancies, gather more dates and to add missing information. Where possible, we accessed state digital files to search the grey literature reports.

We gathered over 104,000 dates from the lower 48 states. We focused on archaeological dates (~87,000) but included those from purely geological (~13,400) and paleontological (~2700) contexts as well. We estimate that these dates represent as much as $30,000,000 (not including recovery costs), most of which came from public funding.

One lab, Beta Analytic, accounts for just over half the dates, and a little over half the dates are on charcoal. Over 80% of the dates contain information on their context.

The database includes over 3000 dates on human bone, teeth, hair and tissue. Knowing that such dates are of concern to Indigenous communities, we included data on whether the date was obtained after consultation with the descendant community; such dates account for about half of the sample. At the moment, human bone dates are masked in CARD until such time as consultation can take place to decide how such dates should be handled.

At present, we are analyzing the data, focusing on an apparent drop in the continental US Indigenous population around AD 1150 (see figure 1; this is a "summed probability distribution, using ~24,000 AMS dates), before European contact. This decline happened earlier in some places, and not until contact in others (e.g., California, New England), but it appears that by the time Europeans arrived in the New World, the Indigenous population had been substantially reduced in many places from a previous peak. We are investigating whether the pre-contact declines are due to already-existing disease(s), warfare, a climate-related reduction in food availability, or all three.
